entry.title: Combined summary - Camouflage: A project dedicated to Hal Finney
entry.summary: A developer named Prayank has initiated a project to improve privacy in Bitcoin, which he hopes will be useful for users and developers alike. The project includes an issue and pull request tracking system related to privacy in different Bitcoin projects, a blog section for Prayank's opinions on privacy issues, and a "Hall of Fame" section to recognize the contributions of developers working on privacy-related improvements. The project is not intended to become a paid newsletter or have sponsors, but contributions to make the website better are welcome. In an email conversation, Prayank shared his observation regarding the use of JavaScript and WebRTC in 'bitcoin-transactions' and 'node-Tor', which he found interesting but noted that users who prioritize privacy often disable both while using a browser. Aymeric suggested adding a discussion/issue on improving privacy in Bitcoin to Prayank's links. Prayank also shared a link to his project called 'Camouflage,' aiming to improve privacy in different Bitcoin projects through issues and pull requests, blog section, and a 'Hall of Fame' section to appreciate developers who contribute to privacy improvements. The project will not turn into a paid newsletter or require any sponsors, and Prayank welcomes contributions to make it better. He provided a link to the current website and mentioned moving everything to a new repository soon.The author of the email wishes to improve privacy in Bitcoin and expresses their admiration for Hal Finney, who they believe could have helped with this effort. They provide a link to one of Finney's posts on the subject and mention having emailed about privacy-related issues on July 23. The author admits their email may not have been focused due to the fact that it was their birthday and they had consumed alcohol. Despite only receiving one response from someone who liked a video mentioned in the email, the author has created a project called Bitcoin Camouflage, which is intended to help improve privacy in different Bitcoin projects. This project includes a section for issues and PRs related to privacy from various Bitcoin projects, a blog section for the author's opinions on privacy-related issues and PRs, as well as a "Hall of Fame" section for appreciating the contributions of developers who are improving privacy in different Bitcoin projects. The author states that the project will never turn into a paid newsletter or require any sponsors, but they would appreciate any contributions to make the website better. Finally, the author invites Edward Snowden to contribute if he wants to do more than just tweet about improving Bitcoin privacy. The author provides two links: one to the current location of the project and another to where it will be moved to this weekend.The email conversation between Aymeric and Prayank revolves around the discussion on using the Tor protocol between Bitcoin nodes via node-Tor. The nodes can be browsers or wallets as well, but the use of Tor browser is neither foreseen nor encouraged. Prayank observes that the project uses JavaScript and WebRTC, which users who care about privacy generally disable while using a browser. Aymeric suggests adding to the links the discussion/issue regarding improving privacy in Bitcoin projects. The links provided in Aymeric's signature include several projects such as move your coins by yourself, Bitcoin transactions made simple, torrent-live, node-Tor, Zcash wallets made simple, Bitcoin wallets made simple, and peersm.
